text:
Hi ... I am/was curious if someone has set up a local or "on-prem" julia package repository? And can point to useful material or best practices for embarking on such an endeavor?
Would syncing the whole julia github package universe be the only possibility and how does one keep track of updates and "potentialy" breaking inter-package dependencies? Am I just not aware of a similar thing or is there also something in place that does some QA (quality assurance) on these things like CRAN for R packages? Plus Julia version compatibility of packages etc.

text:
You don’t need top sync the general registry into your private one.
(you did for Pkg2 back before julia 1,.0 came out, but Pkg3 fixed that)

You can have multiple registries.
I know that :invenia:  and :beacon-biosignals:  do this for there private registries.
packages can depend on packages in other registries.
It just requires the user has all the registries installed.
General disallows this, but i imagine every private registry depends on General except for people in secured sites.
(They probably *do* have a vetted synconized subset of General, I think JuliaTeam can do that)

text:
>  how does one keep track of updates and “potentialy” breaking inter-package dependencies?
Julia packages specify breaking with semver rules.

But to catch people mistakenly not tagging things as breaking, Invenia runs nightly test jobs, with all our private and public packages.

Further for things that are critical not to break downstream we do reverse dependency testing during CI on PRs.
(you can see how that is done on GitHub in the ChainRules.jl repo)
